  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.content.ComponentCallbacks2, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener, ViewController

    public class ViewControllerPlatformFragment
extends android.app.Fragment
implements ViewController
    This class should be used instead of Fragment (android.app.Fragment, non-support fragment).

      • onControllerCreate

        public void onControllerCreate(@Nullable
                               android.os.Bundle extras)
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called when the view controller is creating. This is where most initialization should go (you can think of this method as constructor replacement). Good place to inject dependencies.
        Specified by:
        onControllerCreate in interface ViewController
        Parameters:
        extras - Intent extras (in case of Activity) or construction arguments (in case of Fragment).

      • onControllerRestoreInstanceState

        public void onControllerRestoreInstanceState(@NonNull
                                             android.os.Bundle savedInstanceState)
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        This method mey be called after ViewController.onControllerCreate(Bundle extras) (but before ViewController.onControllerStart()), when the view controller is being re-initialized from a previously saved state, given here in savedInstanceState.

        Controller UI is not yet created, so you must not use ViewController.findViewById(int id) here or modify UI in any other way (eg. showing dialogs or working with fragments). It is better to save the necessary data in the class attributes.

        If the view controller is started without previously saved state, this method will not be called.

        Specified by:
        onControllerRestoreInstanceState in interface ViewController
        Parameters:
        savedInstanceState - The data most recently supplied in ViewController.onControllerSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState).

      • onControllerGetContentLayoutId

        public int onControllerGetContentLayoutId()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called when the view controller wants to create UI. This is optional, and non-graphical view controllers can return zero (which is the default implementation). This will be called between ViewController.onControllerCreate(Bundle extras) and ViewController.onControllerStart().

        If this view controller based on Fragment, than in some cases this method can be called after ViewController.onControllerStop().

        Specified by:
        onControllerGetContentLayoutId in interface ViewController
        Returns:
        Return the layout id for the view controller UI, or zero for non-graphical view controller.

      • onControllerContentViewCreated

        public void onControllerContentViewCreated()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called immediately after ViewController.onControllerGetContentLayoutId() has returned a non-zero layout id (if ViewController.onControllerGetContentLayoutId() has returned zero, this method will not be called). This gives subclasses a chance to initialize themselves once they know their view hierarchy has been completely created.

        Good place to use ViewController.findViewById(int id) (if you don't already use kotlin extensions or data binding) and create adapters for ListView or RecyclerView.

        But you shouldn't register any View listeners (eg. click listeners) here - use ViewController.onControllerStart() instead.

        Specified by:
        onControllerContentViewCreated in interface ViewController

      • onControllerStart

        public void onControllerStart()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called after ViewController.onControllerGetContentLayoutId() (and after ViewController.onControllerContentViewCreated(), if ViewController.onControllerGetContentLayoutId() has returned a non-zero layout id). When this method is called, it means that the view controller is ready for operation (but not necessary active or even visible to user).

        Also can be called after ViewController.onControllerStop(), if the view controller is restarted.

        Good place to register View listeners (eg. click listeners), subscribe to observables or event bus, register broadcast receivers, and reflect last application state into UI.

        NB. Internally this method is called directly from onStart() in Activity or Fragment, so due to nature of Android, calling this method does NOT mean that this view controller is shown to a user at first time (for example, Activity of Fragment can be destroyed and created again after screen rotation).

        Specified by:
        onControllerStart in interface ViewController

      • onControllerResume

        public void onControllerResume()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called after ViewController.onControllerStart() and mean that the view controller is ready to interact with user.

        Keep in mind that this method doesn't mean that this view controller is actually visible to user (a system window such as the keyguard may be in front). Use Activity.onWindowFocusChanged(boolean hasFocus) to know for certain that your view controller is visible to the user (for example, to resume a game).

        Also can be called after ViewController.onControllerPause(), if the view controller is resuming after pause.

        Good place to begin animations and open exclusive-access devices (such as the camera).

        Specified by:
        onControllerResume in interface ViewController

      • onControllerFocus

        public void onControllerFocus()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called after ViewController.onControllerResume() when the view controller gains window focus. This means that this view controller is active, visible to the user and not covered by any other window.

        In most cases, you do not need to override this method.

        Specified by:
        onControllerFocus in interface ViewController

      • onControllerBlur

        public void onControllerBlur()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called after ViewController.onControllerFocus() when the view controller lost window focus. This means that this view controller is still active, but not visible (or partially visible) to the user.

        In most cases, you do not need to override this method.

        Specified by:
        onControllerBlur in interface ViewController

      • onControllerPause

        public void onControllerPause()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called when the view controller is going into the background (but has not (yet) been stopped and killed). The counterpart to ViewController.onControllerResume().

        Good place to stop animations and releasing exclusive-access devices (such as the camera).

        Specified by:
        onControllerPause in interface ViewController

      • onControllerPersistUserData

        public void onControllerPersistUserData()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called immediately after ViewController.onControllerPause(). This is last change to persist important user data, because after this method an application may be killed by Android without calling onStop and onDestroy in Activities and Fragments (in terms of view controller - without calling ViewController.onControllerStop() and ViewController.onControllerSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState)).
        Specified by:
        onControllerPersistUserData in interface ViewController

      • onControllerStop

        public void onControllerStop()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Called when the view controller are no longer visible to the user. You will next receive either ViewController.onControllerStart() (or ViewController.onControllerGetContentLayoutId() in case of Fragment), ViewController.onControllerSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState) or nothing, depending on later user activity.

        Good place to unregister View listeners (eg. click listeners), unsubscribe from observables or event bus, and unregister broadcast receivers.

        Why you need to unregister listeners? See https://stackoverflow.com/q/38368391. Question answer suggests to disable button, but than you should re-enable it in ViewController.onControllerStart(), because the view controller can be restarted. Unregistering listeners seems more straightforward and consistent.

        Specified by:
        onControllerStop in interface ViewController

      • onControllerSaveInstanceState

        public void onControllerSaveInstanceState(@NonNull
                                          android.os.Bundle outState)
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        This method may be called after ViewController.onControllerStop() to retrieve per-instance state from this view controller. For more details see documentation for Activity.onSaveInstanceState(Bundle outState).

        onSaveInstanceState() in Activity or Fragment is not related to lifecycle, and can be called at any time before onStop(), even before onPause() (or after onStop() in Android P). In contrast, this method is always called after ViewController.onControllerPause() and ViewController.onControllerStop().

        Specified by:
        onControllerSaveInstanceState in interface ViewController
        Parameters:
        outState - Bundle in which to place your saved state.

      • getView

        @Nullable
public android.view.View getView()
        Description copied from interface: ViewController
        Returns the content view of this view controller, if non-zero layout id was returned from ViewController.onControllerGetContentLayoutId(), otherwise returns null.
        Specified by:
        getView in interface ViewController
        Overrides:
        getView in class android.app.Fragment
        Returns:
        The content view or null.

        Specified by:
